data.body:
Cross referencing this from the Nifty GUI issue tracker:
https://github.com/void256/nifty-gui/issues/365

Seems to happen due to some timer threads (Timer-0, etc) staying alive even after all other user threads have exited.

data.title: SDK issue checklist

milestone.description:
jMonkeyEngine SDK 3.1

Highlights:
- Gradle
- Native Bullet physics
- NetBeans 8.x
- iOS support

data.body:
(Note: consider splitting these into separate issues)
- [x] The bundled Blender 2.75a is not supported - exported models crash the SDK. One option is to simply update to an older Blender version such as 2.74.
- [ ] Projects from 3.0 SDK are not compatible with 3.1 SDK. For example, native deployment and names of the libraries have changed - hence recreating the project is required.
- [ ] The built-in documentation which is generated from the wiki has broken links - the generator has not been adjusted to the new wiki structure yet. As a result, the welcome page still says "You're using the latest version of jMonkeyEngine SDK (3.0)"
- [X] The terrain editor no longer works correctly - erasing a texture does not work. Also the paint brush seems to be offset a bit from where the mouse is. Fixed in edd183a2be86af90f5bea680fc2b953d8bf0177f
- [ ] In the "Projects" tab, importing a new asset causes it to be selected under "Dependencies" instead of under "Assets".
- [x] The editor is based on NetBeans 8.0, but NetBeans 8.1 has already been released.

data.title: Material "ColoredTextured.j3md" does not contain important Technique definitions
data.body:
While using the SSAOFilter in combination with material "ColoredTextured.j3md" I noticed that geometry using said material was not rendered during the SSAO filter pre-processing step. This is due to the fact that SSAOFilter uses forced technique "PreNormalPass", which unfortunately is not defined in "ColoredTextured.j3md". In fact, it doesn't define any of the many techniques all or most of the other materials provided by JMonkey do.

(I'm using material "ColoredTextured.j3md" to texture my model with a baked texture, that contains all diffuse, light and shadow information and should not be affected by any light. ColoredTextured is the fastest solution to achieve this.)

data.title: JBullet JAR is not properly included as a Maven artifact

milestone.description:
jMonkeyEngine SDK 3.1

Highlights:
- Gradle
- Native Bullet physics
- NetBeans 8.x
- iOS support

data.body:
When uploading maven artifacts, the jbullet and stack-alloc jars are not considered at all. They are not marked as a dependency of the jme3-jbullet artifact nor are they uploaded to the repository via the uploadArchives task. 

This should be easily fixable if somehow those jars can be considered as "built from source" from gradle point of view, then all that is needed is to specify a project + configuration dependency instead of a jar file dependency inside the jme3-jbullet build script.

data.title: Publish maven artifacts to SonaType

milestone.description:
jMonkeyEngine SDK 3.1

Highlights:
- Gradle
- Native Bullet physics
- NetBeans 8.x
- iOS support

data.body:
Would be great if jME 3.1 artifacts could be published to sonatype, as that is the official repository for Maven. 
This would require first setting up an account with them and going through the approval process, then to publish the artifacts by modifying our build script (the "uploadArchives" task) to upload to sonatype instead of updates.jmonkeyengine.org.

data.title: Blender loader does not flip coordinates of UV map
data.body:
In Blender the UV coordinates start in the **lower**-left corner (0|0) and go to the upper-right corner (1|1).
In OpenGL (and thus JMonkey) the UV coordinates start in the **upper**-left corner (0|0) and goes to the **lower**-right corner (1|1).

The Blender loader imports Blender's UV coordinates unaltered and does not flip the v-component of the UV coordinates. Thus, a model that contains UV coordinates and a texture is rendered incorrectly in JMonkey.

Possible fix:
The Blender loader should correct Blender's UV coordinates by flipping the v-component so they work correctly in OpenGL/JMonkey.

It would probably be sufficient to call `flipUV(false, true);` in the constructor of class `com.jme3.scene.plugins.blender.meshes.Face`. But I'm no expert regarding the Blender loader.

data.title: Blender loader handles lights incorrectly
data.body:
JMonkey's Blender loader seems to add all lights (and their LightNodes) to the scene's root node instead of their correct position in the scene graph.

Background:
It is possible in Blender to add lights somewhere down in the scene's hierarchy. For example like this:

```
MyScene
   |-- House
        |-- Porch
            |-- SpotLight
            |-- PorchDoor
```

When loading this simple scene using JMonkey's Blender loader, it will add the SpotLight and its LightNode to "MyScene" instead of "Porch". So the scene graph will look something like this in JMonkey:

```
MyScene
   |-- House
        |-- Porch
            |-- PorchDoor
   |-- LightNode (referencing the SpotLight)
   |-- SpotLight
```

The problem is, that the SpotLight will now affect all of the objects in the scene, and not only the Porch as the artist probably wanted it to.
The LightNode which is created for each light in the scene is also attached to the incorrect parent (i.e. the scene's root node).

(Note: The SpotLight is not actually a Node in JMonkey, but is stored inside the lights list of the "parent" node.)

I added a fix/patch below that will create a scene graph like this:

```
MyScene
   |-- House
        |-- Porch
            |-- PorchDoor
            |-- LightNode (referencing the SpotLight)
            |-- SpotLight
```

You may ask yourself why the LightNode now is added to the same parent as the SpotLight. The reason for this is founded in how JMonkey handles lights.

My motivations are as follows:
- When the artist added the light as a child of "Porch", she wanted only the children of "Porch" to receive lighting from the Spotlight. Thus the light has to be added to "Porch". If it was a child of "LightNode" it would only affect the LightNode itself and its children. (So nothing in our example.)
- But: The artist/programmer still expects the LightNode, which was created for the light, to be at the same position as it was in Blender. So if the Porch moved, the light moves with it.
  Makes sense, right?

Disclaimer: I'm by far no expert on lighting in JMonkey and also have no real knowledge of the source code of the Blender loader. So please thoroughly review may changes in the patch below. And please also make sure that the changes make sense according to my explanation above.

I also want to note that Blender completely ignores the position of the light in the scene graph during rendering. When rendering our example scene in Blender, our Spotlight would affect all of the scene and not just the Porch. (I don't know how Blender's game engine would handle the light.) But this is OK for a renderer that supports radiosity etc. I guess.

Here is the patch:

```
Index: BlenderLoader.java
===================================================================
--- BlenderLoader.java  (revision 5566)
+++ BlenderLoader.java  (working copy)
@@ -242,10 +251,8 @@
                 Structure objectStructure = pObject.fetchData().get(0);

                 Object object = objectHelper.toObject(objectStructure, blenderContext);
-                if (object instanceof LightNode) {
-                    result.addLight(((LightNode) object).getLight());// FIXME: check if this is needed !!!
-                    result.attachChild((LightNode) object);
-                } else if (object instanceof Node) {
+
+                if (object instanceof Node) {
                     if (LOGGER.isLoggable(Level.FINE)) {
                         LOGGER.log(Level.FINE, "{0}: {1}--> {2}", new Object[] { ((Node) object).getName(), ((Node) object).getLocalTranslation().toString(), ((Node) object).getParent() == null ? "null" : ((Node) object).getParent().getName() });
                     }
@@ -253,6 +260,11 @@
                         result.attachChild((Spatial) object);
                     }
                 }
+
+                if (object instanceof LightNode) {
+                    LightNode lightNode = ((LightNode)object);
+                    lightNode.getParent().addLight(lightNode.getLight());
+                }
             }
         }
         return result;
```

data.title: Blender loader ignores Custom Properties of the scenes
Blender Loader crashes for files created with Blender 2.75
data.body:
JMonkey's Blender file loader (com.jme3.scene.plugins.blender.BlenderLoader) crashes when trying to load/import files that where saved with Blender 2.75a. The exact same file loads just fine when saved with Blender 2.74. I suspect a change to Blender's file format. Unfortunately the Loader code is too complex for me to understand/fix myself.

Unfortunately I can't provide a minimal test case, as small Blender files tend to work perfectly. And the affected object/meshes that crash the Loader seem to change randomly when saving the file after doing minor changes to it.

Here is a stacktrace:

```
Caused by: java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException: toIndex = 92
    at java.util.ArrayList.subListRangeCheck(ArrayList.java:1004)
    at java.util.ArrayList.subList(ArrayList.java:996)
    at com.jme3.scene.plugins.blender.meshes.Face.loadAll(Face.java:487)
    at com.jme3.scene.plugins.blender.meshes.TemporalMesh.<init>(TemporalMesh.java:126)
    at com.jme3.scene.plugins.blender.meshes.TemporalMesh.<init>(TemporalMesh.java:98)
    at com.jme3.scene.plugins.blender.meshes.MeshHelper.toTemporalMesh(MeshHelper.java:119)
    at com.jme3.scene.plugins.blender.objects.ObjectHelper.toObject(ObjectHelper.java:171)
    at com.jme3.scene.plugins.blender.BlenderLoader.load(BlenderLoader.java:104)
    ... 6 more
```

Affected revision: 5570

data.title: jmonkey 3.1 native physics bug
data.body:
Hi,sorry for my english
When setting the project to use native physics,adding RigidBodyController to a spatial in the scene editor,the loading that spatial and attaching it yo root node,when calling applyForce,applyImpulse,applyTorque or applyTorqueImpulse makes the spatial disapeare,
Replacing the read() and write() functions of bullet PhysicsRigidBody with the read() and write() functions of jbullet PhysicsRigidBody (with some tweaking) solves the problem.
Last,really thanks for this incridible engine

data.title: Exception thrown when jME application is executed from SMB share

milestone.title: Future Release
milestone.description: Features that will not make it into the next immediate release.

data.body:
```
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: URI has an authority component
    at java.io.File.(File.java:423)
    at com.jme3.asset.plugins.ClasspathLocator.locate(ClasspathLocator.java:88)
```

When running from a path like `\\abc\def\`, jME3 crashes in `ClasspathLoader`:
at  `String path = new File(url.toURI()).getCanonicalPath();`

Creating a File object from an SMB path isn't supported by Java (?)

data.title: Screen Space Ambient Occlusion shader (ssaoBlur15.frag) not working with OpenGL 3+
data.body:
When running an application with the SSAO filter and the renderer set to AppSettings.LWJGL_OPENGL3 a compiler error happens for ssaoBlur15.frag

```
21:13:55.889 [jME3 Main] ERROR com.jme3.app.Application - Uncaught exception thrown in Thread[jME3 Main,5,main]
com.jme3.renderer.RendererException: compile error in: ShaderSource[name=Common/MatDefs/SSAO/ssaoBlur15.frag, defines, type=Fragment, language=GLSL150]
0(202) : error C7533: global variable gl_FragColor is deprecated after version 120
```

Most likely this just needs a proper out variable declared and used instead of gl_FragColor but I'm not shader expert.

data.title: LWJGL 3.x support
data.body:
Need to add support for LWJGL 3.x.

There shouldn't be any issues, except the loss of LwjglCanvas which may break the SDK.
AWT panels need to be stable and working before we can fully make the switch.

data.title: Not calling Mesh.updateCounts() causes negative statistics
data.body: If the user forgets to call `Mesh.updateCounts()`, the vertices / triangles value will be -1, thus causing the renderer statistics to be subtracted and eventually become negative. If the stats value is -1 the mesh should be considered invalid and crash with exception.

data.title: Add capability to ignore user specified anti-aliasing samples
data.body:
When the application is using post-processing, it doesn't make sense to create a context with anti-aliasing since post-processing performs drawing on a separate framebuffer.

Add `AppSettings.setIgnoreSamples(boolean)` to allow the user to specify that post-processing is used so the samples settings should be ignored.

data.title: jglfont-core.jar is missing in nifty-bundle
data.body: I am not sure whether this issue has been reported yet, but in the current version (3.0.10) the lib "jglfont-core.jar" is missing in the nifty-bundle. The lib is inside the jmonkeyplattform/libs, but somehow is missing it's connection to the IDE (if you try to add the .jar via "add library" directly from jmonkey). Additional to that, the javadoc is missing.

data.title: LwjglOffscreenBuffer without Pbuffers
data.body:
`LwjglOffscreenBuffer` currently uses Pbuffers. Unfortunately Pbuffers are not supported by nVidia nSight frame debugger. Would it be possible to implement  `LwjglOffscreenBuffer` using FBO instead?

Would there be some drawbacks / limitations of using FBO?

data.title: Make 'Q' and 'Z' move flyCam along its up vector
data.body: In FlyByCamera, rather than hardcoding them to be along the Y axis, 'Q' and 'Z' now move with and against respectively whatever direction has been set as its up vector (using setUpVector).

data.title: Ambient light in PBR shader
data.body: Any plan to add ambient light support in PBR shader?

data.title: light constructors
data.body: per discussion at http://hub.jmonkeyengine.org/t/new-contributor-wants-to-submit-small-usability-tweaks/33150. The new constructors have been added in such a way as to preserve existing functionality whereby most direction and light data are copied during set\* operations.

data.body: t is less than 4

data.title: Merge pull request #1 from jMonkeyEngine/master
data.body: Merge

data.title: Bullet RigidBody : added support to vector3f based AngularFactor & LinearFactor
data.body:
This modification allow to "lock" a degree of freedom of one rigidBody, without joint. This ability is only available with native bullet. 
This can be useful for using bullet for 2D game (maybe not the best option), this can be done like so : 

``` java
body.setAngularFactor(new Vector3f(0,0,1)); // <-- only rotate on Z axis
body.setLinearFactor(new Vector3f(1,1,0)); // <-- only move on a 2D plane (X-Y)
```

You can also set a value between [0;1] to "reduce" the movement / rotation. 
Using angular/linear factor do not preserve the conservation of energy. (the factor only scale the "forces")
